medical_history.history_of_present_illness: The patient was in his usual state of health until 12 days before admission, when 2 days after discharge from a detoxification clinic, he self-administered heroin intravenously. Two days later, symptoms including fever, chills, cough, myalgias, anorexia, and malaise began, alongside gradual onset of joint swelling and pain, an erythematous and nonpruritic rash, and severe diaphoresis. Initially, the joint symptoms affected the ankles, then progressed to the knees, hands, and elbows over 3 days, accompanied by weakness of the arms and legs. The patient rated the pain at 10 on a scale from 0 to 10. Symptoms of redness in the eyes and neck pain were reported, but he had no headaches or changes in bowel or urinary function.
